The game is great, if you like over the top hilarious action. Just don't expect too much fulfillment from the gameplay. A lot, if not all of this games charm comes from its sense of humour. The combat and gameplay elements though, tend to get a bit stale... There are points where you'll fight one guy for a long time, repeating the same pattern over and over until you win.. It can be rough.. But if you can go into trance mode for the combat, then I'm sure you'll find the story fun.. Would totally recommend, especially if you catch it on sale..\n\nI also forgot to mention, some sections of the game just feel very buggy... Numberous times I grabbed on to thing air, pulled myself up, and fell to my death on some platforming sections.. Or tried going a certain direction while in the air, and get pushed way in the opposite by mystical forces..

This game is pretty kickass.

Don't dismiss this as a paltry God of War clone. It's a pretty good, bombastic, blacksploitation version of God of War for PC. If you've played God of War (or Dantes Inferno for that matter), you'll know the score here. Constantly dancing dealing death with bright weapon trails between simple platforming and puzzle sections.

What's great about this game is the standard it sets. For such a small game, it really tries to stand out next to the AAA titles it mimics. The plot is a rather generic, tale of afterlife, revenge and rescuing a damsel in distress. The whole game uses voodoo and industrialism as it's theme, much like God of War uses greek mythology and the Underworld.

The graphics are pretty spectacular for such a short and budget developed game, with some excellent framed vistas which can be compared to the Uncharted series, the soundtrack can sometimes be repetitve and tiresome but the game is complimented by funny banter between Marlow and the titular Mask of Death, heckling Marlow's 'tough guy' one liners, in a sense, a buddy movie dynamic and not to far away from what the reboot of Shadow Warrior does. The game is full of Hollywood typical explosion visuals and solid sound effects.

Occasionally, the game takes you by surprise and ejects you into a minigame of a race collecting orbs, sliding down pathways avoiding obstacles, or a magnificently over the top on rails shooting section shooting helicopters down from the back of a moving vehicle and finally a top down arcade shooter much like Capcom's 1942 series, which is a pleasant diversion,

The game took me eight hours to beat in total and if experienced to the hack and slash format, platforming and puzzles that GoW delivers, you'll find no problems getting through the game. Much like GoW acquired weapons and abilities can be upgraded, but the selection is very, very limited and it's incredibly easy to upgrade the weapons using collectable orbs.

The controls are pretty solid and translated for mouse and keyboard, much like Blades of Time, (another PC hack and slash game), my only issue is using magic abilities using the complicated layout of holding down left control and a numberic key 1-4, which can make fights difficult if you want to attempt to use a magic move to wear enemies down. The boss fights are nothing spectacular and are just more or less obstacles from one section or another or purely acquiring a new ability. There is also no opportunity of back tracking in this game whatsoever and for that matter, nothing to backtrack for.

Even the credits are a bit of fun, you can tell the developers had a lot of fun making this title and it's totally worth a blast for a quick action/adventure/hack and slash title if you want to give it 6-8 hours. You might find yourself pleasantly surprised.

I'd like to say I like this game, but anybody who looks at my time played sees that I don't have the experience to justify that. I can't get the dialogue to work, and I've been trying for an hour. Just know that, upon installation of this game, dialogue may or may not work. I'm not going to bother playing it right now with these audio problems, but it's likely not going to be that way for everyone. Just know that this is a problem that exists.

Anyway I had to make this revieuw because alot of negative comments saying  Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Boredom" but thats just stupid. Add me on steam if we have games incommen so we could play or if you want to have a chat ;-) -Slash *out*"
For the price it's at (£1.80), its a great game, sure it's a bit buggy and the cutscences are clunky, but at least they reconise that and have an achievement to skip them all.
If you play this you'll be ♥♥♥♥♥in explosions and burping fire, extremely fun and EXTREMELY over the top but in a good way. Worth 8$\nJust don't take this game seriously.

Pros
This game is silly...and it embraces it! The cut scenes are almost a parody on typical Hollywood action movies, and their style is unique and beautiful (although after a while, it may become tedious to some, but you skip them). You've got an intesting 'companion' which constantly is either making fun of you, guiding you, or cheering depending on the situation.
If you're into silly humor and action-adventure hack&slash games, you'll totally love this game! It has some great puzzle sections which require some thought, but not too hard to make you get stuck.
You start with one weapon, but every hour or so you either get a new weapon or a new magic skill, which broadens your arsenal and keeps the combat fresh. Each weapon is the most efficient against a certain type of enemy, and that makes the combat interesting.
The game has a really nice checkpoint system, so that if you die, you almost never have to complete a whole section again. This fixed a frustration that I have with many games nowadays that use a checkpoint system. You also have the option to save manually.

Cons
I would've liked some more enemy variety for regular mobs though. While the boss monsters are quite nice and unique, the same regular enemies keep coming back during the game (but to their credit, they sometimes add a new variety to the insect/human mix).

Conclusion
I've clocked in at around 8 hours to complete this game, which was perfect. It provides constant action and it pushes you forward because of it.I was constantly looking forward to the next encounter, weapon upgrade or silly jokes.
I picked this game up during the sale, but knowing what I know now, I would've even bought it outside of a sale.

Very fun. New weapons, powers and enemies every so often keep it fun. The mask has some hilarious one liners. Very humorous game.\n\nNot going to win any awards for graphics though. And the camera can sometimes ruin your combo. Would only recommend if you really want the game or it is on sale.

At first glance, and from popular opinion, this game will seem like an underrated, cheesily self-aware but still-enjoyable spectacle-fighter at a budget price. And it is largely those things, but it's still not far from being mediocre.

What the game has going for it is its cheesy, self-aware humor, and it did a great job of delivering on it. I smiled and got some genuine joy out of that aspect quite a number of times. I also enjoyed the set-pieces and technical-efficiency of the game. But past those, it's pretty much your run-of-the-mill CAG/hack-n-slash.

After the novelty wore-off for me (maybe 2 hours in), I started to get increasingly bored as I progressed because the combat just didn't deliver. It's your standard button-masher where victory comes relatively easily, and where Hard" mode doesn't make the game more difficult

Pretty fun game, if you can appreciate/stand a cheesy, over-the-top 80's action flick style experience (both in the humor and the game itself). It's a spectacle fighter with fairly decent gameplay, very good for the price point, I'd say.  Think God of War centered around Rambo's black cousin.

A lot of the attacks don't really feel like they have a lot of weight to them, especially with the Whip, because the enemies don't really react like they were hit or get staggered in any way. The attacks certainly at least look pretty though, and some combos feel very satisfying. Generally the combat system is fairly fleshed out imo. There are a lot of combos and each of the four weapon types has their own combo system.

My biggest problems with the game are the camera and the fairly frequent crashes. Unless I missed something you have no control of the camera at all. It generally gets the job done but often picks some angles that wouldnt exactly have been my first choice, and sometimes gets kinda awkward. And the game definitely has some stability issues. I don't know if it just hates my machine, but I'd say I crash probably once per 20-30 mins. The games usually fun enough for me to relaunch it and keep going though. But I do strongly advise you to make frequent saves. The checkpoint system is generally alright but doesn't to add more buffers in case you crash (or fall into a pit in a platforming section).

Other less major complaints would include a few turret sections that I didn't love but at least they weren't THAT long or overly frequent (think i've had 3 in a couple hours of gameplay), a few kinda annoying QTEs but again not that many or very long. I could have also lived without the audio-clips from Marlow's girlfriend but I think they can be skipped if they bug you enough.

The game does have some puzzle and platforming elements that you may or may not enjoy. Persnally I thought the platforming was just challenging enough to not be boring but it didn't get frustrating or overstay its welcome. If nothing else the companion makes a few funny remarks when/if you fail. The puzzles so far have generally been pretty simplistic and I could live without them but can also live with them.

Generally I'd say I've had a pretty good time with the game, and the positives have outweighed the few problems I've had with the game. The gameplay is pretty enjoyable and I personally rather like the humor with the banter from the companion, the villain, and the occasional 4th wall breaks. Got it on sale for like $1 and I definitely got my money's worth.. and then some.

If you dont hate it within 5 minutes, then you will probably like it. it doesnt really do anything all that wrong, and the graphics are quite lovely. The gameplay is just good enough to not frustrate or bore you, and something about the setting and voice acting keeps you immersed. Cant find much bettter for the price.

note: I played this with an Xbox 360 controller.

If you liked God of War, you will probably like this. It has a bit less polish but the game doesn't ever take itself seriously. There's 4 different weapons, 4 different powers, and probably 9-10 combos for each weapons. There's no chaining, no real reward for doing combos. Getting hit doesn't interrupt your combo, but it will push you back in most cases making you sit in a recovery time (which will probably run out the combo timer). It's closer to an arcade beatemup than a cuhrazee game.

The very last weapon you unlock has great weapon feel. It's too bad it was the last one because I really wanted to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of more enemies with it. The base weapon has a pretty mediocre feel, the second weapon has nearly no response, and the 3rd has a pretty cool aoe hitbox, so I'll let it slide.

There's puzzles in the game, but none that are of any difficulty. However, they're new" feeling enough to not feel boring.
I laughed a few times in the game but for the most part it's a pretty cliche "an ancient evil awakens (literally)" storyline. It's not absurd enough or meta enough to really hold my interest too much though.

The graphics are pretty well displayed

This game is solid in the controls, has great action, knows how to have fun and is a great, cheap b-movie game. Has some niggles, but totally worth it.

Starts well, never changes. Lovely environments. Trivial gameplay. Terrible playable credits which ruin your perception of the creative team. Not really worth it overall, except as a demonstration of how pretty a game you can make on a budget.

This is actually a really great game! Think of it like if Michael Bay made a God of War like game. There are tons of explosions with some platforming with a mediocre storyline. The mask is actually quite witty with some very funny death monologues. The fighting style is easy to work with and doesn't require any kind of controler. This game is a lot of fun though a tad on the short side. Definitely worth the 3 bucks I paid for it and I know that everyone who plays it will enjoy this little jewel of a game.

Very strange action game. A combination of Devil may cry + monster hunter tri + Soul Calibur and that scene in star wars: phantom menace where anakin tames the wild beast in the arena. You also get a really annoying mask that talks to you, gives you meaningful advice, but at most times a bit too talkative for a ceremonial deathmask. It even makes fun of you when you fall off and die in the platforming parts of the game. But there's a lot of work done for just $5. If you like Jax from Mortal Kombat series or a luke cage fan, and want to play as an overpowered, black american sacred warrior, you might want to pick this up.

This game surprised the hell out of me. While it is nothing more than a God of War clone, it also starts off more exciting than any God of War, well paced and exciting. The problem is in the fact that the game falls apart toward the end, falling into the typical pitfalls of the character action genre, where you spend more time fighting sponges that prolong the game than feeling like you're actually accomplishing something. The first half is where the game is exceptionally entertaining but beyond that, be prepared for monotany.

That said, for a cheap-♥♥♥ game like this, it sure has great value. Good graphics, sound, and gameplay. The story is weird and silly and the cutscenes seem to come out of nowhere sometimes, but that's part of the cheap-o charm. The game itself, as I said, is a God of War ripoff unabashedly. Which means it has the problems of God of War. Some weapons are completely useless, and the stupid enemies that go underground and burrow up elsewhere are here as well. When emulating or copy and pasting a game, at least leave the bad portions out.

This is a short, fun, and cheap game that will appeal to character action fans. I won't give it a wholehearted thumbs up, but I do think it is worth your attention.

Is it worth the $6.24 I paid for it on sale? Totally. Is it worth $14.99? No. I would wait for a sale and buy it. For what I paid, it's a very good game. Would I recommend playing it? Sure. It's worth a shot. Very, Indiana Jones meets Prince of Persia: The Forgotten Sands.

Action and adventure, served up with a liberal dose of Death-God humour.  Add in a villain voiced by the amazing James Hong.  Worth playing simply to hear the villain's commentary to his henchmen while the base is being dismantled by our hero (commentary given in the form of public announcements regarding firings via intercom), Marlow Briggs is a great bit of platforming fun.  It's powered by a 3-D engine, and the camera is on rails, but as a bargain title, it more than delivers its quota of fun.

An imperfect but enjoyable cinematic brawler. This is the gaming equivalent of fast food. Cheap but filling if you enjoy this type of gameplay. There are certain design elements that left me scratching my head, such as the story being told during slow motion cutscenes, which seem to be there only to extend playtime. The story itself, is nothing to write home about, infact, its rather terrible, but that isn't wan't this game is about. Its just mindless fun.

Zootfly, they made ... Expendable 2, before this one...
One of the shitiest game ever.

So a 3.50€ game made by them, I wasn't really expecting something from this game.
But this game rocks, it's badass, enjoyable, fun, funny and speed.
Of course don't expect a AAA quality, but as an indie, it's a great achievement.

You know those games where the trailer for it is far more enjoyable to watch than the game itself? That is, thankfully, not how this game is. It reminds me alot of Darksiders but with a more linear progression through the story ( you are trying to save your girlfriend so why wouldnt you just head straight to the goal?! ). So far I just love this game. Buy this now or wait for a sale, either way, buy it!!

Well, I had a blast with this. It's like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ love child of God of war - Tomb Raider - Uncharted and a little Dante's Inferno. Yes it's a little rough around the edges and has all the character of a bad Saturday morning B-Movie, but it just so much fun. For the price it's a no brainer. The level design and environments are brilliant. Camera can be a bit awkward but stick with it and you get the hang of it. Best $5 I have spent I think.
If this were a movie, it'd be a mid-90's straight-to-video special starring a guy who once co-starred in a Schwarzennegger flick. As a throwback to the action-platformers of old, it's decent.

Personally I thoroughly enjoyed the 7 hours I spent playing this game.

You'll enjoy this game if:
- You like hack and slash games with very simple puzzles (God of War, Dantes Inferno, Darksiders etc.).
- You enjoy getting new abilities/skills and trying different combos.
- You like over the top and incredibly unrealistic happenings (half of it is like a Michael Bay film).

You won't like this game if:
- You'e looking for a big, open and immersive world. It's very linear though very pretty.
- You don't like lots of stupid things happening.
- You want a game to play for 10 hours plus, I think that'd be a struggle with this.

All in all I would highly recommend it, if I had to give it a rating I guess it would be around 8/10.

This is literally the best thing ever made.

Decided to write a small opinion about the game since almost no-one from my friendlist have it in their library.

tl;dr: I liked it. Really funny spectacle fighter/brawler game.

More:
It's a your-standard-generic-brawler game, like any DmC or Batman games this days, yet it offers a nice original story to it placed in Mayan ruins (or Aztecs, or Toltecs, or w/e ;)). There are small glitches here and there, the combat system is not as refined as in DmC, but it was a pleasure playing it.

You are a man who visits your Ancient South America (later referred to as ASA) linguist girlfriend and suddenly you are killed because reasons (not only monsters, but people as well don't like you in this game). However, the weapon you were killed with was possessed by some god of ASA and he recognizes you as The Spirit Warrior who will bring peace to this part of Earth. And so you get resurrected and have a scythe to get through hoardes of mercenaries, possessed mercenaries, ASA warriors and other monsters and gods from ASA believes.

During your progress you get more weapons (in total: scythe, rouge-like weapon - my fav, whip with a blade and warhammer with one side bladed) as well as learn some magic by defeating gods (fire, earth, ice and wind). Spells are summoned by using mana.

You replenish you health by collecting red orbs/masks and mana by collecting blue ones. Your abilities can by upgraded by collecting enough of yellow ones. However the upgrades are simple: each weapon and spell has three levels, and with each level you get more dmg with it, unlock 2 new moves and your health or mana base value gets higher. It's much simpler than in e.g. Darksiders: there you needed to think what to put your exp into, but here, as the weapons and spells are added to your arsenal in balanced manner, almost always you'd get one thing upgraded before having the other one obtained. With that in mind, the fight system is extremely expanded and the actions you get through sometimes are the typical Hollywood star Bruce Willis level of awesomeness actions.

The biggest issue I had with the game was the mana system. When you are fully upgraded you get to fire exactly 2 spells. But the mana bar doesn't indicate you in any way if you have enough mana to cast the spell, so you mash the buttons once or twice trying to see if it can work. As stated previously, mana is obtainable in form of blue masks (placed directly on map) or blue orbs (flying out of defeated opponent). As fights are mostly in closed area arenas with god-knows-how-much-opponents going to jump at you in next wave (if there will be any, who knows), you try to limit the usage of blue masks nearby. After you die two or three times to some bigger tank monsters and even start using the masks because why the hell not, you find yourself in a place where you need a smallest amount of mana to use the spell one more time, but it doesn't regenerate in time, and isn't replenished with inflicted damage, so you spend time and time until you finish the monster, and voila, blue f-ing orbs which you don't need anymore. And before next fight it is certain that more than one blue mask will appear.

Another problem I had were some mini-missions/challenges where you would slide down and had to avoid rocks, pits etc. Alice: Nightmare Returns had some similar sequences, but in here the time between when you push the jump button and when it is registered by the character in game was many times too big for me and I've spent countless times on some of those agility jobs.

And one smallest issue: the game needs some power to run smoothly. On my machine DmC was running 60fps on 1080p max settings while this one had to be changed to 720p and some of the graphic options needed to be disabled. I know that Unreal Engine which DmC was running on was tended professionally through years, and I have no idea what was Marlow Briggs build on, but I would expect a little more from the game fidelity.

Except of those two and a half points above the game was really nice: the story was addictive, the fight system, combos included, was sensationally developed and fluent, graphics caught your eyes and had some great sceneries and the music was always on spot. Also, your mask-god companion has a great sense of sarcastic humour and the voice acting for it is great, so you don't get bored.

Having in mind that it is actually a budget game (€5 without a sale) this is probably one of the best fun to price factor games you can get right now.

I do recommend this totally underestimated game, give it some love, ref!
A silly, stupid, very fun game. A low-budget game done well, doesn't drag on, and is absolutely worth a playthrough.

The Good:
* Fun environments and action cutscenes
* Decent sound and characters
* Great production values and campy action movie fun

The Bad:
* Probably plays better with a gamepad
* Feels very console like
* Some cheap deaths and overly hard jumping puzzles

Background: Bought for pennies in a steam sale

Impressions: Very impressive game for a budget price. The action cutscenes are over the top and fun with random explosions and yelling.

Recommended for: Those who like 3rd person console-like action run around games with a sense of humour

Conclusion: 6/10. MoowhooWah Ha Ha.

An absolute gem by a relatively unkwnown company, Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death operates on the fact that it knows it's a low-budget character action parody of B-movies, and manages to nail it perfectly. Great voice acting, a script with great banter, beautiful vistas, and a surprisingly good combat system, the only flaws I found with it were the lack of proper options and slight framerate drops during cutscenes and moments where the action got too intense. The whole game has been a ridiculously fun rollercoaster the entire way through so far, and I recommend buying it while it's so cheap.\n\n
The Deadly Premonition of Action Games

Imagine God of War with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ animations, mediocre graphics, boring puzzles and level desings, bland story and characters, unfair combat and cutscenes that 95% of the time are 3D slideshows.\nIf this game has any redeeming features it's the decent voice acting.\nAll in all, only buy this game if it's 80% off or more and it would still barely be worth its price.

Easily the most underrated game I have ever come across. It is start-to-finish fast-paced hack-n-slash third-person action and fun set-pieces, only slowing down due to the incompetence of the player, yet even then the game is always pushing you in the right direction. At one point I was stuck and the Mask (companion) gave hints within 1 minute of me running around, and another minute later told me to just push the cart into the pistons, which was all I had to do. The game is also very forgiving with a ridiculous frequency of checkpoints.
I wasn't even caring about the collectibles and the game still lasted me about 6 hours, 6 hours of straight and varied action with just a touch of puzzle-solving, no filler whatsoever. Looking back the combat seemed a little repetitive, though I guess that was just me using the same combos over and over. People are right when they say it is similar to God of War, though GOW is not on PC....

The game has an incredibly low asking price on steam, let alone sale price. In terms of value for money, this game is definitely up there. It is easily the best purchase of the summer 2014 sale for me, and one of the best steam purchases ever.

Yeah, it's a God of War game. The parts that aren't God of War are clones of other games you probably know. However, I found it difficult to get bored because the game goes batshit crazy at a breakneck pace. It's laugh-out-loud exhilarating and heart-pounding hilarious.

It belongs to an elite class of games like Killer Is Dead and Monkey Island - while you're playing, the game seems to be having as much fun as you are.

You can tell that it was made on a shoestring budget - every unncessary corner has been cut, but no shortcuts were taken where it counts. Cutscenes are kept to frozen key frames, but those frames are gorgeous. The characters are simple, but fantastically acted. Combat's just God of War, but it's God of War done very right.

Issues include some minor control issues during platforming and some awkward camera angles, but these are the rough edges of an uncut diamond. Even when I got frustrated with repeating one section over and over again, I couldn't stay mad for long before a beautiful view and a great kill animation had me cackling with delight.

9.5/10

Pros:
I already want a sequel.

Simple controls.

Cons:
Somewhat repetitive battles
This is also a 360 game. which becomes obvious very quickly while playing. That's not a complete con, but any preparations made for other console ports you play should be taken here.
Don't expect a plethora of settings, the game is very slim there. It seems to run well, but there's also not much to change.
Personal gripe: Marlow has gigantic hands, a model in which his face almost never changes, and a weird jump animation.
Personal gripe: Did not find the helicopter shoot 'em up minigame transitions enjoyable. There's only two of those specific minigames, and they are very short. It's extremely fun, very funny, cheap, linear and kinda short.

reviewText: I totally recommend this game. I expected something terrible, like Garshasp or Unearthed, but this game is actually pretty good. Not good like it's a AAA game, but good like in a B-Movie way. The developers knew they were making a God of War clone, and they put a lot of humor pointing that out. It's a fun game with some minor gameplay issues and some glitches, and it has some funny moments. I'd recommend it.

Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death (MBATMOD) is a very fine, small Hack-and-Slay action adventure in the likes of God of War and Devil May Cry. It resembles God of War in many ways, you got 4 different weapons, each unlocked at a certain point in the story, 4 different kinds of magic (which aren't that balanced..), and orb-like collectables to upgrade your magic and weapons. it got a very good combo training system. nice visuals for a small title, at certain points it can easily be compared with AAA-titles. but over all that you got the worst screen-tearing! real xbox360 feeling ;) but it doesn't get in the way of the fun you can have with this title. grab it for a discount price and it's a steal! I got around 5hours gameplay on medium. ah, and the difficulty level likes to spike sometimes..so, now go and buy it already. cheers!

Wow, This game is amazing for the price.  Brought this game for 99 cents and have enjoyed it so much!  As everyone has said it is like playing God of War. I enjoyed the God of War series and I have enjoyed this game in the same manner.  The play mechanic seem simpler, the puzzles are simplier but the fun and graphic are still there. I have not had this much fun playing one of these games since Bayonetta.   Again if you like playing these type of games, I believe you will be pleasantly surprised by this game.

A little jem of a game. I do not ever recall this game being advertised but it is a good game.

The main villian is trying to get immortality. He enlists the help of your girlfriend. When she decides to leave they kill you to make her finish her work. You are brought back to life to stop this guy from getting supernatural abilities. As far as the plot goes, that is about it.

For a pretty straight forword storyline, you travel to many locations and fight a good variety of creatures. The boss battles are interesting and cool looking.

The things that will annoy you  in this game are first off the talking mask that follows you. He is not very informative and seams to suffer from exceptional hindsite. Secondly at certain parts of the game (mostly when getting new upgrades or end of boss battles) the game does a stop motion revolving take of what is going on. As it turns the scenes change and then you go on into the next area. Way to often! Lastly THE INVISIBLE WALLS. there are times when you plan a jump only to hit an invisible wall killing you prompting that mask to make another snide remake about how that should not of happened.

All in all it is a good game with decent fighting mechanics. Not a very hard game but something that will hold your attention for some time.
this is an underrated jewel. Some corny acting but its meant to be similar to a micheal bay movie so its to be expected but the action is non stop and you never get bored i love it.

A fun, humorous, and low cost, hack-and-slash (a la God of War), with a little Tomb Raider tossed in.  Could do with a sequel, but is just as good as a stand alone title.\n\nMarlow Briggs is definitely worth the price and should be in any button masher's library.

There are reviews out there saying that this game is one of those that is so bad that it's good. I don't know what they are smoking. Sure, given it's low price i can understand that many start the game with low expectations about it. But i found this game amazing, deserving well more than 5 bucks. As soon as you get to the main menu, you are greeted to one of the best epic main menu songs out there. Everytime i started the game, i couldn't help but listening to the music for at least 2 minutes. The rest of the music are ok, but this song makes up for all of them. Now speaking of the game, it's a ripoff of God of War, but a pretty good one. The story surely sucks, but there's plenty of funny dialog. The graphics are decent and the game is surprisingly well optimized for PC. Now speaking of the gameplay, it's mostly an Hack and Slash. There's a light and a heavy attack that you can combo, and a grab, block and jump buttons. There's 4 weapons and 5 magic powers that you collect, and they all play differently. You can also upgrade them. The combat is good, with a solid variety of enemy types and bosses, but blocking fells a bit off because you can't block in the middle of an attack, so you'll be evading most of the time. Besides combat, there are also sections of platforming (those could be better), puzzle solving, evading obstacles, 3D shooting and top down shooting. Together, it'll last about 6 hours, and if you are like me, you'll play right again on the hardcore difficulty, which isn't really that hard except for some encounters later in the game. For it's price, it has a good lenght. And you can also replay some challenges from the story in the menu with leaderboards, but for me only the first time was added. Probably a bug, but didn't care much about it. And there's also a minigame in the credits, which sucks but lets you skip the credits the faster you complete it. It was a nice addition to finish the game. In the end, the game isn't brilliant, but surprisingly good given it's price, and you should definitely get it if you're a fan of Hack and Slash games. And one sale, it's a steal.

So here's the deal: Marlow Briggs is just an average dude, visiting his girlfriend Eva somewhere in the jungle of South America, working for an old chinese man, translating mayan artefacts. Unfortunately Marlow gets killed with an ancient weapon and his girlfriend is kidnapped. Instead of dying, Marlow gets infused with an ancient power, becoming the sacred warrior, whose prophecy it is to protect the the old artefacts. His only aim is to rescue his girlfriend and stopping the old chinese of destroying the world. Xibalba can wait. Under the guidance of his new buddy, a flying mask, he starts to fight everything the jungle and militia have to offer - or he is just making some damn silly jokes. The gameplay isn't special. It's a God of War/Devil May Cry clone, but the copy works flawless and is entertaining and challenging. The optics are nice and the soundtrack is very good. All in all a very solid game for a low price.\n\nBonus: the most creative use of endgame credits. People with long names suck!

Game felt as though it was dragging. Though it's a parody, the humor aspect seemed weak. The thing that bothered me the most about this game was DRM. I had to be online to play the game, if my internet was spotty, it would kick me back to the menu and lose my progress. I would not recommend this game for the reasons listed above.
If you've played and enjoyed any of the God of War games and have a gamepad, then I HIGHLY recommend this game to you.

reviewText: Marlow Briggs was surprisingly good. Let's be clear here. This game is a shameless,  complete ripoff of God of War in everything except that it takes place in modern times and features South American mythology instead of Ancient Greece. I chuckled everytime I came across a new mechanic that was lifted straight from God of War. The graphics in this game are really good for a budget title. The locales in the game are a bit generic. There isn't anything that hasn't been seen before. The gameplay is broken up somewhat by sections where you're flying a plane and the game plays out in the style of a top-down shooter. There are also sections where you are sliding down a hill and are going for the quickest time down it.  It took around 7 hours to finish the game. It really was easy. There were only a couple times I had to re-fight battles. I usually died from misjudging jumps.  If you are in the mood for another God of War type gaming experience on the cheap, then I heartily endorse Marlow Briggs.
Sleet, sleet, sleet; pure class.\n\nCompetent and fun as well.

Admit it.  We all loved God of War.  When those games first hit the market, videos games as an industry woul never be the same.  In a market that constantly demands innovation, development of new concepts and methods of interaction, it can be easy to forget how amazing certain tried and true formula can be.  I STILL love playing God of War...  and this game, is a shameless clone/update, call it what you will.  Graphically upated, and skinned in a different mythos, Kratos becomes Marlow.\n\nThis games isn't promising anything revolutionary.  It also refuses to take itself seriously.  The production value is solid, the voice acting well done.  The narrator that is Marlow's spirit guide" i suppose
date: is constantly making wise cracks.  I found the game delightful.\n\nEvery time I wanted to put the controller down
recommended: it kept pulling me back in...  a familiar feeling.  It isn't perfect and it doesn't reinvent the wheel
hoursPlayed:
but it brought back a play style and experience that I feel you don't find enough in modern gaming.  I think someone described it as being able to play a 90's action blockbuster....  fairly dead on.

Get it on sale and you will not be dissapointed.  It's FUN.  Engaging and you will not have to think to hard.  Everyting in it takes place on an epic scale.  An abundance of great Mini-games too.

I am not finished with the game at this point.  I did notice the absence of any MEGA boss fights (Kratos vs the hydra  or kraken) but perhaps those are to come."

An absurd game that's essentially God of War developed by Michael Bay sooo lotta explosions. You're some black guy with an Ooka Ooka ally trying to save your girlfriend and thwart an asian man's evil intentions. The game is self aware. You're not meant to take the game seriously and that's why it can get away with its level of ridiculousness. Your exchanges with Ooka Ooka are very frequent and well done. When you're not focusing on these funny chats, you're spinning till your winning. The combat is blatantly a God of War rip-off (which doesn't bother me) so its free flowing and satisfying with a nice variety of weapons, spells and movesets. It's a kill anything that moves type of affair and the over the top cutscenes just add to the wonderful chaos. It's a daft decoration of death and destruction and you should play it because of that.

Enjoyed it quite a bit, the dialogue and characters are passable and often pretty hilarious.

The cutscenes have, a..for the lack of a better term, sequential art style, that I really liked.

Worth it.

Game felt as though it was dragging. Though it's a parody, the humor aspect seemed weak. The thing that bothered me the most about this game was DRM. I had to be online to play the game, if my internet was spotty, it would kick me back to the menu and lose my progress. I would not recommend this game for the reasons listed above.

I honestly wish that I could have liked this more, but I really just found it to be alright. It's definitely worth the money that they're asking for it, but there are a few flaws that made the game not nearly as enjoyable for me. The worst flaw for me was definitely the fixed camera. For the most part, the camera was in a place that was okay, but at some points, I would have killed to actually be able to move it at some parts. The platforming early on also really aggravated me, as it is somewhat awkward and difficult to get used to. That isn't really that big of a deal though, and it shouldn't be too much of an issue once you progress into the game. I also didn't really like how the game basically just turned into me mashing one button for all of the fights, since I didn't feel very rewarded to do combos in fights. There is also a weapon later in the game that basically stun-locks most opponents if you just do the three hit strong attack combo. Other than those gripes, I did enjoy the game, and I'd say that it's very much worth your money to buy it.
Very cheap, fun fighting system, absurd (in a positive way) story, setting and minigames. Definitely worth playing for the price.

Marlow Briggs is a fun game, action packed game with tongue-in-cheek B movie style humor and fun God of War style gameplay.

Marlow Briggs isn't exactly breaking any new ground however a good game doesn't need to break new ground to be fun and an enjoyable experience. Sometimes it's the games that just want to have fun that make you enjoy your time with them the most. Marlow Briggs fits this description so aptly. The voice acting is decent but still has the cheese to really emphasize the B movie style. Marlow is actually voiced by Pierce from the Saints Row series.

The combat is solid with a lot of combos. You're given the ability to do light and heavy hits, but there's no automatic counter attack button which means that you still need to pay attention to the game to win. The enemy variety is rather decent. You'll fight bugs, big guys who want to melee you and guys with rocket launchers and flamethrowers. The enemies are dispatched kind of simuilarly but the amount of combos at your disposal means that you can vary it up yourself.

The game is about 6-8 hours in length depending on how you play.


Overall an enjoyable experience and a steal for $5. Highly recommended.

A Paladin's Steam Review: Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death. Low Budget Spectacle Fun.Genre: 3rd Person Action Spectacle Fighter.
Developed & Published by: Zootfly & 505 Games.
Platform: Windows and Xbox 360.
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
I’m not entirely sure what you can expect from such an obvious low budget videogame. But being fun isn't one of those things normally. This game is surprisingly solid both mechanically and its story, even if it takes neither of those things seriously. The effort put in shows. Sure, the game’s plot is as 2-dimensional as a standard platformer and the character's don't have much of a backstory but it's pretty darn fun. Especially when you have a SHMUP sequence thrown at you and doesn't feel out of place. The game switches between action spectacle and puzzle/platforming to keep things moving.

Story Thoughts
You follow the adventures of Firefighter Marlow Briggs who gets killed by an industrialist voiced by the noodles guy from Kung Fu Panda. (It sounds like him and I’m pretty certain it is, but the credits don't say and IMDB doesn't credit him with the part). The guy who is voice acting him is clearly having tons of fun with the role. There is so much ham and cheese to his villany, you can't help but giggle. After being resurrected by a Mayan Mask of Death, Briggs must fight through hordes of enemies and gods in exotic Mayan locations to save his loved one from the evil industrialist before he achieves his ultimate goal of becoming a Mayan God. The story is rife with mentions of Mayan culture and their gods.

Combat Mechanics
You get the use of a weird scythe-like weapon which has three other versions of itself as well as four elemental powers you can use to devastate numerous enemies. The different variations allow you to attack in different ways and with different spells. One is a mace-like weapon that's slower but hits harder. Another is a scythe for faster if weaker attacks and so on. The hack and slash elements are well done and flashy, if standard. You recover health and mana via other death masks items found in the level as well as off fallen enemies. The only hidden items in this game are XP masks and they aren't too hard to find.

PC Settings and Audio/Video
Marlow Briggs has a fairly lacking options menu. Game will only display in 16:9 resolutions (with 50, 59, 60Hz options for some resolutions). It’s letterboxed or cropped depending on the differing aspect ratios. AA, V-Sync, Field of View and anisotropic filtering can’t be changed. The AA used seems to be FXAA according to PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. Keys can be rebound if needed though I suggest running this game with a controller. You should be fine without one but spectacle fighters tend to play better with a controller. Audio sliders include: effects, music, dialog and master volume. Can’t go wrong with those choices.

Graphics are a modern day realistic style. It's ok but a bit low-fidelity. Soundtrack is an over the top orchestral collection of tracks with big bombastic choirs singing. There is one thing I should note. Many of the “cutscenes” are a collection of still images of Briggs in a, for lack of a better term, badass pose. Whether its slicing enemies apart or leaping over a boulder, it doesn't matter. Sort of like a very fancy 3D slideshow. I still can’t tell if the devs were saving money, being artsy or confident in their graphics team. It’s a little weird when you're playing the game but I guess it works. Oh one final note, there are challenge modes but I didn't really bother with them.

Final Thoughts
Summed up, Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death is an average game that somehow kept me entertained the entire time. I think the combination of over the top action, voice acting and a care-free attitude in the developers is why. The pace is just about right too. This isn't game-of-the-year material, it’s not the best of the genre and its not a unforgettable experience but Marlow isn't trying to waste your time either. Each level doesn't outstay its welcome and the combat remains challenging without getting too aggravating. Characters are fairly well fleshed out too and you get some reason to care about them. So, consider picking it up if you need a new spectacle fighter.

I honestly wish that I could have liked this more, but I really just found it to be alright. It's definitely worth the money that they're asking for it, but there are a few flaws that made the game not nearly as enjoyable for me. The worst flaw for me was definitely the fixed camera. For the most part, the camera was in a place that was okay, but at some points, I would have killed to actually be able to move it at some parts. The platforming early on also really aggravated me, as it is somewhat awkward and difficult to get used to. That isn't really that big of a deal though, and it shouldn't be too much of an issue once you progress into the game. I also didn't really like how the game basically just turned into me mashing one button for all of the fights, since I didn't feel very rewarded to do combos in fights. There is also a weapon later in the game that basically stun-locks most opponents if you just do the three hit strong attack combo. Other than those gripes, I did enjoy the game, and I'd say that it's very much worth your money to buy it.

I don't tend to finish games that I don't like so much...I just finished Marlow Briggs. I find it a bit strange that this game didn't make more of an impact, anyways it's a real steal now and a somewhat hidden gem. It's a basically an ACTION packed arcade brawler, platformer, shoot-em-up, slide-em-down...you name it :), but importantly the difficulty level is just right, even some of the tougher boss battles just require a bit of learning rather than MLG level hand-eye co-ord and reaction speeds. So yep, I loved it.

I STILL love playing God of War...  and this game, is a shameless clone/update, call it what you will.  Graphically upated, and skinned in a different mythos, Kratos becomes Marlow.\n\nThis games isn't promising anything revolutionary.  It also refuses to take itself seriously.  The production value is solid, the voice acting well done.  The narrator that is Marlow's spirit guide" i suppose

reviewText: I haven't written a review on Steam before, but with this game I thought it was necessary. I haven't even finished the game yet and I already know this was a good purchase. It's a pretty basic Hack n' Slash game, the combat and combo system actually feels a lot like Dante's Inferno on the PS3/XBox 360. The storyline is mediocre and the dialog is pretty cheesy at times, but this isn't what the game is about. This game is about ridiculousness and knowing it's ridiculous with simple and satisfying combat. Plus it has James Hong (the Chinese Samuel L. Jackson) as the bad guy! Definitely worth the $4.99! If I had to rate it 1-10 for what it is - 7.5/10

As a preface, I got this game for 99 cents from the Humble Bundle winter sale.  For one dollar, it wouldn't take a lot to impress me.  However, this game is pretty fun.

Cons:
-No new ground
-Not much variety
-Forgettable music

Pros
+Great main character!
+Pretty decent action platformer
+Good graphics for a budget game

Probably the best part of the game is the cheesiness of the constant action.  The explosions, cliffside leaps, jumping from flying helicopters, etc. almost never stop.  I usually don't like action movies much, but this game handles itself very well.  It knows there shouldn't be so many explosions, but it lets you know right out of the gate that this is how it is going to be and jokes about it the entire way.

I like the combination of solid action mechanics and platforming.  The addition of difficulty settings helps the cause as well.
Honestly, it is a good thing the game only takes about 6 hours to beat.  If it were any longer it would wear you out and get boring.  It is just long enough to introduce the characters and humor, let you get in some good fights, power up, and then it is done, inviting you to come back later on to try a harder difficulty.  Everything considered, it is definitely a game I will go back to every few years for a quick start-to-finish run.

What do you get when you cross Darksiders with God of War? The answer is... well, lots of things actually, but Marlow Briggs is perhaps one of the least well-known of the various clones that have spawned as a result of the aforementioned combination. It's a budget title with little in the way of innovation or originality, and its lumpen, cheese-tastic story is nothing to write home about, but in here lurks a fun, respectable, though flawed action game.

Perhaps the best thing about Marlow Briggs is that the action rarely lets up, as it shifts from set piece to set piece, never really giving you a chance to get bored as you deal with waves of enemies by using a variety of combos to slice them to pieces. Throughout the 6-7 hour campaign you're furnished with a number of new weapons and magic powers, all of which are then upgraded via XP that you earn from kills and pick-ups. Along the way you'll find plenty of health and mana pick-ups too, helping you to replenish your stock ahead of the next big fight. It's a relatively simple system, and the combos aren't too difficult to master, though you'll probably stick to a couple of good ones and use those throughout. Along the way you'll be taking out human enemies, insects and spirits, along with a few boss battles to spice things up, and all with a smooth, easy-to-learn control scheme.

Honestly, I was really enjoying Marlow Briggs up until around the halfway mark, where the game then insists on giving you incredibly tanky enemies that take far too long to kill, artifically increasing the difficulty and the length of the game in doing so. As fun as it was to slice and dice my way around, I felt like the tanky enemies began to detract from the enjoyment of the game, with spirit creatures that disappear every few seconds, forcing you to spend longer running around as you slice away at them until they finally go down. I began to get frustrated with some of the enemy encounters in the second half of the game, though unlocking some weapons and powers did help to satisfy my desire to finish out the game. These encounters won't kill the appeal of the game for you, but they might make the last few hours of it less palatable.

It's hard not to recommend Marlow Briggs at just £4. You're getting a decent game, and you may even improve the experience a tad by dropping the difficulty level down to Casual (I played on Normal), where the tankier enemy encounters that pop up constantly in the second half might be a bit more tolerable. I was impressed that the game has a bit of gusto, and though I encountered a few bugs and glitches, it was a smooth experience overall. There's a bit of humour and self-awareness to the whole thing, and the game never takes itself too seriously. Oh and James Hong is in it, and he's pretty much playing Lo Pan from Big Trouble in Little China again. So if that's not going to sell you on it, I'm not sure anything will!

3rd person action platformer including all the cliche of these kind of games with some B-movie plot and humor. None of the parts of this game is really perfect, but as an overall game it is quite good.

Everything is in this game you would expect and more: turrent sections and vertical scrolling shooter sections, sliding while collecting orb section etc. These sections are of proper length, not outstaying their welcome. I really liked the design of the gigantic ore harvester which is one of the major area's you play on.

The combat is a bit button mashy, but satisfying enough. Some of the jumping puzzles and fights can get a bit frustrating, for example by respawn points just a bit too far away or some cheap deaths not really your fault or that it is not very clear what is expected to do next.
Pro - Marcel Briggs and the Visage of Fatality is a gorgeous, enjoyable brawler with excellent B-Movie humor.\nCon - Michael Bay wants his explosions back.

reviewText: Fun Gameplay and good humor. A fresh air in this genre

Playing Marlow Briggs is playing through a walking paradox. No game with this small a budget should look this good, no game with this small a team should PLAY this good, and no premise as absurd as this should work as well as it does. Yes, it's short, but it's also dirt cheap, and the four hours I spent on this game alone make it an incredibly worthwhile experience. It's funny, amazingly well paced, looks great and has some suprisingly good combat for being a God of War clone. It's a game I think everyone should play at least 20 minutes of, so they can see and bask in the glory of Marlow ♥♥♥♥ing Briggs.\n\nWhat i'm trying to say is that you should play this game because it's really damn good.
You want God of War on the PC, well here it is. It's anm over the top action movie setting, but it works well and the game plays well.
